head.title: Fly the Ozone Back Into the Stratosphere

hedline.hl1: Fly the Ozone Back Into the Stratosphere

block.p: With the upswing in Soviet-American relations, the United States and the Soviet Union are in a position to increase the level of superpower scientific cooperation and trust by initiating a joint atmospheric research project.

A modest cut in defense on both sides - 1 percent - could free billions of dollars, as well as other resources, both human and material, that could be combined to monitor and possibly even combat the problems of ozone depletion and the proliferation of greenhouse gases, particularly carbon dioxide.

The ultimate goal of these efforts, if possible, would be the large-scale synthetic production of ozone and the placement of the stuff back into the upper stratosphere (where it belongs) by means of spacecraft, high-flying aircraft, high-altitude balloons and so on.

The difficulties of such a task may seem enormous, but remember that ozone is a pollutant in some large cities because of its presence in automotive exhaust - which implies that it is relatively easy to produce. Ozone becomes beneficial as a screen to ultraviolet radiation only when it is in place 30 miles in altitude above the surface of the earth, in the uppermost portion of the stratosphere. Given the rapid pace of scientific and technological advancement, we cannot simply discount the possibility of a scientific solution. THOMAS A. BERGSTEIN Albuquerque, N.M., July 12, 1988
The writer is a geologist at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History.
